body.name: Nonfiction: A Novel
body.description: "Raw-nerved and plangent."—The New Yorker"Entrancing."—ELLE, A Best Book of 2024 “Glitteringly painful.”—Rachel CuskThis is definitely not a ghost story. But for a while after you’re gone, I see you everywhere. Every ragged young person sitting huddled on a pavement, every stretched-out body under cardboard in a shop doorway.Two parents stand by powerlessly as their only child seems intent on destroying herself. As the mother—a novelist—attempts to understand her daughter, she finds herself revisiting her own uneasy, unresolved relationship with her mother. Weaving between childhoods past and present, laced with temptation and betrayal, Nonfiction: A Novel is an unflinching account of a mother, daughter, wife, and author reckoning with the world around her. But can a writer ever be trusted with the truth of her own story?Clear-eyed, lacerating, and fearless, Julie Myerson’s Nonfiction: A Novel explores maternal love as an emotional foundation to both crave and fear. A hauntingly beautiful and deeply moving love letter from a mother to a daughter, this is a tale of damage and addiction, recovery and creativity, compassion and love. Read more

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 1, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Real Powerfully Written & Very Much Needed!
reviews.reviewText: This author offers an up-close, and no-fluff view of the impacts addiction causes the person inflicted, as well as those that love them. This writer is bluntly honest and brings out the very real challenges and exhausting pain that are a part of the disease of addiction. This book also explores the many confusing aspects of human relationships and manages through very creative and insightful writing to also bring to light uplifting strengths and true kindnesses that are also born within when human pain is understood rather than judged. I highly recommend this book AND feel it's desperately needed for all USA readers too!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 18, 2024
reviews.reviewText: The story goes back and forth and it kept me wondering. I cried a lot. I recommend this book. I also plan to read more by Julie Myerson.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 2, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars painful but worthy read
reviews.reviewText: A novel that some will find extremely difficult to read. An unnamed narrator, an author, tells her story and that of her drug addicted daughter in a way that feels like one long confession of doubt and generational trauma. The narrator had a fraught relationship with her own mother and over the years has questioned how she deals with her child. Myerson, who previously wrote about her son's addition, has turned the situation on its head to proclaim that this is fiction and then titled it Nonfiction. Except the details are so real. Thanks to netgalley for the arc. A painful one.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 30, 2024
reviews.reviewText: An emotional cluster of generational trauma and its impacts. Mothers and daughters. Writers and drugs. The whole book is told by a narrator that provides very fluid timelines. This was confusing in parts attempting to understand what happened to who and when. Ultimately, the reader experiences the uncertainty of how to keep those we love safe and cared for.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 2, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Heartbreaking story of family and addiction
reviews.reviewText: This is an absolutely heartbreaking and fascinating novel. The unnamed narrator is a novelist, and through her writing she works through her relationships with all the other unnamed characters: her mother, her husband, her daughter, her affair partner, and her mentee. The book explores relationships and how they change over time, addiction, and trauma as it is passed down through families. It was beautifully written and so compelling to read.Thanks to the publisher and NetGalley for the gifted copy.
